repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
> [!NOTE]  
> This PR is **purely experimental**. PR contains some basic set of tests which are passing. There is failing test with compilation of shared library using limited API (this is known and ignored for now)

This PR implements offloading C Utility code to shared library. The saved size depends on the amount of utility code used in the compiled module. My experiment shows that compiling `ParseTreeTransforms.py` will save ~50 kB with default setuptools build and ~7kB when debug symbols are removed from resulting .so file (`strip -S ParseTreeTransforms.cpython-311-x86_64-linux-gnu.so`)

## Usage
Building is the same as in curent branch described here: https://cython.readthedocs.io/en/latest/src/userguide/source_files_and_compilation.html#shared-utility-module

## Potential improvements

* Current implementation focuses allowing to offload C utility code to shared library. Hence, I avoided more complex refactoring of C utility code. Hence, several other functions could be offloaded after some utility code restructuring. E.g. `__Pyx_State_RemoveModule` could be moved to shared utility module after moving to separate utility section + small other changes:
  https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/b67b7ce6e6788f52ae75630c1e42abedabee80e0/Cython/Utility/ModuleSetupCode.c#L3001
* Several function declarations are encapsulated within macros - e.g.
https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/b67b7ce6e6788f52ae75630c1e42abedabee80e0/Cython/Utility/ObjectHandling.c#L411-L421
For those more complicated code generation is needed (but theoretically can be done).

## Downsides
* Not sure whether the saved space is worth of code complexity.  *Maybe* if shared module would be distributed as separate library shared across multiple projects as dependency would be worth it but this opens another can of worms (maintenance of shared library etc...)
* Not all shared functions can be offloaded to shared module. Shared functions *must not* be called before this line:
  ```c
  /*--- Global type/function init code ---*/
  (void)__Pyx_modinit_global_init_code(__pyx_mstate);
  (void)__Pyx_modinit_variable_export_code(__pyx_mstate);
  (void)__Pyx_modinit_function_export_code(__pyx_mstate);
  if (unlikely((__Pyx_modinit_type_init_code(__pyx_mstate) < 0))) __PYX_ERR(0, 1, __pyx_L1_error)
  if (unlikely((__Pyx_modinit_type_import_code(__pyx_mstate) < 0))) __PYX_ERR(0, 1, __pyx_L1_error)
  (void)__Pyx_modinit_variable_import_code(__pyx_mstate);
  (void)__Pyx_modinit_function_import_code(__pyx_mstate);      // <= After calling this function we can start using shared module functions
  /*--- Execution code ---*/
  ```
  Otherwise compilation is successful but loading the module will end up with segmentation fault.

Let me know what do you think about it. Is the complexity worth the gains?

comment_data.body:
Please refactor this into a declarative, constant list of configuration to make it easy to read and maintain:
```suggestion
# this constant can go to the top-level:
_shared_utility_code = [
    # Please keep this list alphabetically ordered.
    ("Buffer.c", [
        "BufferFormatCheck"
    ]),
    ("Coroutine.c", [
        "CoroutineSetYieldFrom",
        "pep479",
    ]),
    ... # etc.
]

    def generate_shared_c_utilities(module_node):
        use_utility_code = module_node.scope.use_utility_code
        load_utility_code = Code.UtilityCode.load_cached

        for utility_code_file, sections in _shared_utility_code:
            for section in sections:
                use_utility_code(load_utility_code(section, utility_code_file))
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -27,6 +27,33 @@ def generate_tree(compsrc):
 
         return generate_tree
 
+    def generate_c_utilities(module_node):
+        module_node.scope.use_utility_code(Code.UtilityCode.load_cached("BufferFormatCheck", "Buffer.c"))

@@ -180,6 +180,8 @@ static void __Pyx_BufFmt_Init(__Pyx_BufFmt_Context* ctx,
                               const __Pyx_TypeInfo* type); /*proto*/
 
 /////////////// BufferFormatCheck ///////////////
+//@shared_params: __Pyx_BufFmt_CheckString::const char*::__Pyx_BufFmt_Context*, const char*
+//@shared_params: __Pyx_BufFmt_Init::void::__Pyx_BufFmt_Context *, __Pyx_BufFmt_StackElem *,const __Pyx_TypeInfo *

comment_data.body:
To me, this option is a bit of a red flag, indicating that there should be a better way to handle requirements for shared code. Maybe we can restructure the shared code to exclude parts that depend on module local requirements?  OTOH, it doesn't really hurt to duplicate transitively used utility code across both the shared module and the user modules, does it? If both use that code, then both need it and both should have a copy. So, why do we need the case that utility code requirements should *not* be included?

If the refactoring is the issue currently, I'm fine with starting smaller and only sharing the code that is easily extracted, and then doing the refactoring later on top of that.
This would be better expressed with a "verbose" regex by now.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -462,7 +462,7 @@ def load_utilities_from_file(cls, path):
             rstrip = partial(re.compile(r'\s+(\\?)$').sub, r'\1')
         match_special = re.compile(
             (r'^%(C)s{5,30}\s*(?P<name>(?:\w|\.)+)\s*%(C)s{5,30}|'
-             r'^%(C)s+@(?P<tag>\w+)\s*:\s*(?P<value>(?:\w|[.:])+)') %
+             r'^%(C)s+@(?P<tag>\w+)\s*:\s*(?P<value>(?:\w|[.: *()&,])+)') %

comment_data.body: This was just "experiment" to see how I can shed size of binary. I wanted to do it without major refactor of utility code. That's why the PR is marked as experimental and is not intended to be merged in any case.
I wanted to avoid parsing of the code because I consider it fragile. Constructing C code is easier then parsing although I agree with you that this is much more readable.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -180,6 +180,8 @@ static void __Pyx_BufFmt_Init(__Pyx_BufFmt_Context* ctx,
                               const __Pyx_TypeInfo* type); /*proto*/
 
 /////////////// BufferFormatCheck ///////////////
+//@shared_params: __Pyx_BufFmt_CheckString::const char*::__Pyx_BufFmt_Context*, const char*
+//@shared_params: __Pyx_BufFmt_Init::void::__Pyx_BufFmt_Context *, __Pyx_BufFmt_StackElem *,const __Pyx_TypeInfo *

comment_data.body: I was thinking that shared module can scan all C utilities and search for exported/shared functions. In this case we won't need configuration too...
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -27,6 +27,33 @@ def generate_tree(compsrc):
 
         return generate_tree
 
+    def generate_c_utilities(module_node):
+        module_node.scope.use_utility_code(Code.UtilityCode.load_cached("BufferFormatCheck", "Buffer.c"))

comment_data.body:
I think it's doable to parse this with a regex. It's really just "a bunch of characters for the type ending with a space or a star, followed by a straight `\w+` function name, followed by parentheses that encapsulate a bunch of characters describing the arguments".

Struct arguments might be more difficult, though, as we'd also need to provide their declarations if they are not globally available.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -180,6 +180,8 @@ static void __Pyx_BufFmt_Init(__Pyx_BufFmt_Context* ctx,
                               const __Pyx_TypeInfo* type); /*proto*/
 
 /////////////// BufferFormatCheck ///////////////
+//@shared_params: __Pyx_BufFmt_CheckString::const char*::__Pyx_BufFmt_Context*, const char*
+//@shared_params: __Pyx_BufFmt_Init::void::__Pyx_BufFmt_Context *, __Pyx_BufFmt_StackElem *,const __Pyx_TypeInfo *

comment_data.body: That would be much better, right.

+    def generate_c_utilities(module_node):
+        module_node.scope.use_utility_code(Code.UtilityCode.load_cached("BufferFormatCheck", "Buffer.c"))

commit.message: Initial implementation of shared C utility code
Multiple functons can be shared now
Add new shared functions + fix import issue

title: Experiment: Allow to share C utility code
